title: What would be the cost of the Louisiana Purchase in modern money? - Quora

response.answer_text: WOW!!!!!! FRANCE finally selling the Louisiana Territory. Poor Tom Jefferson could of saved us a lot of money if he hadn’t failed in his bid to buy it from Napoleon for $15,000,000, back in 1803, or in today’s dollars about $350 million. The French Ambassador when asked why France is now selling the Louisiana Territory, said, “We got bills to pay.” Pressed further, one of his aides spoke off the record: “You Americans have settled our Louisiana territory. You’ve carved states out of it. You assume it as part of your nation. And I must say, so did we French. “However, one of our auditors, stumbled across the deed and found that America hadn’t fulfilled all the terms of the agreement. so technically America defaulted.” “Technically defaulted?” asked a stunned reporter. “Oui! Oui! To the sum, how do you American say the next number more than a trillion-” “A zillion dollars?” shrieked the reporter. “3 or 4 of those,” stated the aide. “You’ll bankrupt us!” cried the reporter. “Yes, we know that. That is why we are seeking seven percent of the present evaluation of our territory as a final sales price.” “How did you arrive at that price?” asked the reporter. “Our auditor calculated that the original sales price was seven cents an acre, and made his calculations from there. After all, you Americans are all squatters, oui, oui?”

I’m going to come at this a bit differently. The actual purchase price was not in dollars, but in French francs. In 1803, the French franc was worth 290.034mg of gold. The United States paid 68 million francs, for a total of 19,722 kg of gold, or a touch over 634,000 troy ounces of gold. At the present spot price of gold of $1233 per ounce, that’s $781,955,000 or so. Actually, we did not have to deliver that much gold, because a portion of the purchase price involved the U.S just forgiving French debts owed to the U.S. of around 18 million francs. Of course it was quite a steal, since dear old Napoleon was desperate for cash for the wars in Europe. If we were to re-sell it back to France today, I expect we’d charge a bit more. That area probably represents around 20% of U.S. GDP, or around $3.5 trillion or so annually. If you figure that the value is some low multiple of gross product, it would be worth about $10 trillion or so as an ongoing concern. So if we sold it we could pay off around half the national debt.
